description: Examples for language vocabulary flashcards - lexical learning, word meanings, translations

examples.title: German Vocabulary - Urteil
examples.back_explanation: A formal decision made by a court or judge. Used in legal contexts and figuratively for personal judgments.
examples.back_mnemonics: Cognate with English 'ordeal', from Proto-Germanic *uʀdailijan ('to mete out or allot'). Historically an 'ordeal' was a form of judgement (by God).

examples.title: Spanish Vocabulary - Contento
examples.back_explanation: Adjective expressing happiness or satisfaction. Must agree in gender with the noun it describes.
examples.back_mnemonics: Think 'content' - when you're content, you're happy

examples.title: French Vocabulary - Se dépêcher
examples.back_explanation: Reflexive verb meaning to hurry oneself. Conjugates as: je me dépêche, tu te dépêches, il se dépêche, etc.
examples.back_mnemonics: Dépêche sounds like 'dispatch' - dispatch yourself quickly!

examples.title: Italian Vocabulary - Pranzo
examples.front_question_hint: Masculine noun, main meal of the day
examples.back_explanation: In Italy, 'pranzo' traditionally refers to the main meal of the day, usually eaten between 1-3 PM.
examples.back_mnemonics: Pranzo sounds like 'prance' - you prance to lunch when hungry!

examples.title: English Vocabulary - Meticulous
examples.front_question_hint: About being very careful and precise
examples.back_explanation: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise. Often used to describe work quality or personal characteristics.
examples.back_mnemonics: Think 'met-ick-ulous' - so careful you notice every icky detail

examples.title: German Vocabulary - Laufen
examples.back_explanation: Strong verb meaning to run or walk. Note the vowel change in present tense (er läuft) and the past forms.
examples.back_mnemonics: Laufen = 'laugh' + 'en' - you laugh when you run with joy

examples.title: Portuguese Vocabulary - Saudade
examples.back_explanation: A deep emotional state of nostalgic longing for something or someone absent. Often considered untranslatable and uniquely Portuguese/Brazilian.
examples.back_mnemonics: Saudade contains 'sad' - the sad feeling of missing something dear

examples.title: Japanese Vocabulary - Ashita
examples.front_question_hint: Common time word, can be written in hiragana or kanji
examples.back_explanation: Basic time word meaning tomorrow. Can be written in hiragana (あした) or kanji (明日). Pronounced 'ashita'.
examples.back_mnemonics: A-shita sounds like 'Ah, she-ta' - Ah, she took tomorrow off!
